text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Foreign Minister Amr Moussa said Egyptian efforts to save the Middle East peace process and break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians would continue, in spite of the gap between them, which is still large.
- A high-level Egyptian delegation will take part in meetings at the United Nations in New York to follow up the Rio Earth summit of 1992.
- President Hosni Mubarak started a short trip to Germany yesterday. He also received a phone call from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on his peace initiative.
- Elections for the head of the Journalists Union will take place tomorrow.
- A senior State Department official said the U.S. administration expects that a Senate subcommittee will "correct" the foreign aid package which neglected to set aside aid money for Cairo.
- Mubarak's talks with French President Jacques Chirac had very important results.

- Health Minister Ismail Sallam said he had submitted a draft law on organ transplants to Grand Sheikh of al-Azhar Mohamed Sayyed Tantawi, who had approved it. The law will be studied in cabinet and at the Council of State. The law sets the rules for organ tranplants in a way that respects mankind and prevents wrongdoing.
- The International Monetary Fund (IMF) missioin which visited Egypt recently said in its report to the board that the economy is growing by at least five percent.

- Thailand intends to complain that Egypt is obstructing Thai tuna exports by amending the specifications. Egypt recently required exporters to obtain a certificate of guarantee from the Egyptian embassy.

- Planning is under way with Austrians for the biggest ever tourist project on the northwest coast. The first stage of the project, which has Arab capital, would include eight hotels and the second phase would build another nine.
- The foreign ministers of the Damascus Declaration states will meet in Latakia in Syria next Wednesday to discuss peace, a security protocol and a common market.
- Three terrorists were killed yesterday in a battle with security forces in Beni Suef. They were found with three pistols, 153 rounds of ammunition and 1,973 pounds ($580).
